│ │                                                         │ line. To stay inside the square, we probably need the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle that is below the line y = (8/a)x, which     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ would curve downward.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But this is getting complicated. Maybe there's a better │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ way. Let's parameterize the problem.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Suppose the diameter connects a point on the bottom     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ side (x1, 0) and a point on the right side (8, y1). The │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter length d is sqrt( (8 - x1)^2 + y1^2 ). The     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center of the diameter is at ( (x1 + 8)/2, y1/2 ), and  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the radius is d/2. The semicircle must lie entirely     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ within the square. Therefore, every point on the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle must satisfy 0 ≤ x ≤ 8 and 0 ≤ y ≤ 8.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The semicircle is the set of points (x, y) such that (x │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - (x1 + 8)/2)^2 + (y - y1/2)^2 = (d/2)^2, and (x, y)    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ lies on one side of the diameter line. Since we want    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle inside the square, we take the side of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the diameter that is towards the interior of the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square.                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ To ensure the semicircle is entirely inside, the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ farthest points on the semicircle from the center must  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ not exceed the square's boundaries. The maximum         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x-coordinate on the semicircle will be ( (x1 + 8)/2 ) + │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (d/2) * cos(theta), where theta is the angle from the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center to the point. Similarly for y-coordinate. But    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ this might not be straightforward.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, since the semicircle must lie entirely   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ within the square, the distance from the center to each │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ side of the square must be at least the radius in the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ direction perpendicular to that side. Wait, no. Because │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle is only a half-circle, so maybe only     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ certain directions need to be checked.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, think of the extremal points of the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle. The semicircle will have a highest point, a │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ lowest point, a leftmost point, and a rightmost point.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ All of these must lie within the square.                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But the position of these extremal points depends on    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the orientation of the semicircle. If the diameter is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ not aligned with the axes, then the extremal points     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ might not be straightforward.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps the maximum diameter occurs when the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is tangent to three sides of the square. For │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ example, tangent to the bottom, right, and top sides.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me check that.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If the semicircle is tangent to the bottom, right, and  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ top sides, then its center must be equidistant from all │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ three sides. But a semicircle can't be tangent to three │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sides unless it's a quarter-circle, but we have a       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle. Hmm, maybe not. Alternatively, if the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is tangent to two adjacent sides and the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ third side is touched by the arc.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's suppose the semicircle is tangent to the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ right, top, and left sides. Then, the center would have │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to be at (4, 8 - r), with radius r, but this is a full  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle. Wait, no. For a semicircle, the diameter would  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ have to be positioned such that the semicircle curves   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ towards the center of the square.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ This is getting too vague. Maybe a better approach is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to model the problem with coordinates.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let’s consider the square with vertices at (0,0),       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8,0), (8,8), and (0,8). Let’s place the semicircle     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ such that its diameter has endpoints on the bottom side │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x1, 0) and the right side (8, y1). The diameter length │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is d = sqrt( (8 - x1)^2 + (y1 - 0)^2 ). The center of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the diameter is at ( (x1 + 8)/2, y1/2 ). The semicircle │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is the set of points (x, y) such that the distance from │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x, y) to both endpoints of the diameter is equal to d. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no. Actually, the semicircle is all points on the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle with diameter d that lie on one side of the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But maybe parametrizing the semicircle's equation is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ better. The general equation of a circle with diameter  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ endpoints (x1, 0) and (8, y1) is:                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x - (x1 + 8)/2)^2 + (y - y1/2)^2 = (d/2)^2             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ where d = sqrt( (8 - x1)^2 + y1^2 )                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The semicircle would be either the upper half or the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ lower half relative to the diameter line. Since we want │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle inside the square, we need to choose the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ half that is towards the inside. Given that the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter is from (x1, 0) to (8, y1), the semicircle     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that is inside the square would be the one that curves  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ upwards and to the left, into the square.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, we need to ensure that all points (x, y) on  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ this semicircle satisfy 0 ≤ x ≤ 8 and 0 ≤ y ≤ 8.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ To find the maximum d, we need to maximize d = sqrt( (8 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - x1)^2 + y1^2 ) subject to the constraint that the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle lies entirely within the square.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let’s consider the extremal points of the semicircle.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The topmost point of the semicircle will be important   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ because it could hit the top side of the square (y=8).  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, the leftmost point might hit the left side   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x=0). So maybe the maximum d occurs when the           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is tangent to the top and left sides of the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square.                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So let's set up the equations for the semicircle being  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ tangent to the top side y=8 and the left side x=0.      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, the semicircle's equation is:                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x - (x1 + 8)/2)^2 + (y - y1/2)^2 = (d/2)^2             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ And we want this semicircle to be tangent to x=0 and    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y=8.                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For tangency to x=0, the distance from the center to    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x=0 must be equal to the radius in the x-direction.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, not exactly. For a circle to be tangent to a      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertical line x=0, the distance from the center's       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x-coordinate to 0 must be equal to the radius.          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, for tangency to y=8, the distance from the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center's y-coordinate to 8 must be equal to the radius. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait, the semicircle is only half of the circle, so │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ tangency might not require the full distance. Hmm,      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ actually, even if it's a semicircle, if the circle is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ tangent to a line, then the entire circle would be      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ tangent, but since we're only taking the semicircle,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ maybe part of the circle is outside, but the semicircle │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is entirely inside. Wait, no. If the semicircle is      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ entirely inside, and the full circle is tangent to a    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ side, then the semicircle must also be tangent at that  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ point.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, if the semicircle is tangent to x=0, then    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the center's x-coordinate minus the radius equals 0.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, if it's tangent to y=8, the center's         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y-coordinate plus the radius equals 8.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's recall the standard equation for tangency.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For a circle with center (h, k) and radius r, tangent   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to x=0 requires |h| = r, and tangent to y=8 requires |k │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - 8| = r.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But since the semicircle is in the square, the center   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (h, k) must be such that h ≥ r (if tangent to x=0 on    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the left) and k ≤ 8 - r (if tangent to y=8 on the top). │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but if the semicircle is tangent to x=0, then the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ distance from the center to x=0 is h = r. Similarly,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the distance from the center to y=8 is 8 - k = r.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, h = r and 8 - k = r, so k = 8 - r.           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given that the center of the circle is at (h, k) = ((x1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + 8)/2, y1/2), so:                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x1 + 8)/2 = r                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y1/2 = 8 - r                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore:                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x1 + 8 = 2r ⇒ x1 = 2r - 8                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y1 = 2(8 - r) ⇒ y1 = 16 - 2r                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Additionally, the diameter d is sqrt( (8 - x1)^2 + y1^2 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ )                                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Substituting x1 and y1:                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d = sqrt( (8 - (2r - 8))^2 + (16 - 2r)^2 )              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 8 - (2r - 8) = 8 - 2r + 8 = 16 - 2r                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So,                                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d = sqrt( (16 - 2r)^2 + (16 - 2r)^2 )                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = sqrt( 2*(16 - 2r)^2 )                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = (16 - 2r)*sqrt(2)                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But d is also equal to 2r, since the diameter of the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle is 2r (wait, no). Wait, hold on. Wait, the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle has diameter d, so radius d/2. But in this case, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the circle we're considering is the one with diameter   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ between (x1, 0) and (8, y1), which has length d = sqrt( │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8 - x1)^2 + y1^2 ). However, we've set up this circle  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to be tangent to x=0 and y=8, so its radius is r, which │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ we used in the tangency conditions. Wait, maybe there's │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ confusion here.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, hold on. Let's clarify:                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If the semicircle is part of a full circle that is      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ tangent to x=0 and y=8, then the full circle has radius │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ r, centered at (r, 8 - r). Then the diameter of the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle must be a diameter of this circle. However,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle could have any diameter, but in our      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ case, the diameter is between (x1, 0) and (8, y1). So   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ perhaps we need to reconcile these two ideas.           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, the circle centered at (r, 8 - r) with radius r.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Then the semicircle with diameter between (x1, 0) and   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8, y1) must be part of this circle. Therefore, the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter of the semicircle is a chord of the circle.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but the diameter of the semicircle is supposed to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be a straight line, which for a semicircle is the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter. But in this case, if the semicircle is part   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of the circle centered at (r, 8 - r), then the          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ endpoints of the diameter must lie on the circle.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, this is getting tangled. Let's step back.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Suppose the semicircle is part of a circle tangent to   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x=0 and y=8. Then the circle is centered at (r, 8 - r)  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ with radius r. The semicircle must have its diameter as │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a chord of this circle. The endpoints of the diameter,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x1, 0) and (8, y1), must lie on the circle.            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, both (x1, 0) and (8, y1) must satisfy the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle's equation:                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x - r)^2 + (y - (8 - r))^2 = r^2                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Plugging in (x1, 0):                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x1 - r)^2 + (0 - (8 - r))^2 = r^2                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ => (x1 - r)^2 + (8 - r)^2 = r^2                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, plugging in (8, y1):                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8 - r)^2 + (y1 - (8 - r))^2 = r^2                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So let's solve the first equation:                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (x1 - r)^2 + (8 - r)^2 = r^2                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Expand (x1 - r)^2:                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x1² - 2r x1 + r² + (8 - r)^2 = r²                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So x1² - 2r x1 + r² + 64 - 16r + r² = r²                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x1² - 2r x1 + 64 - 16r + r² = 0                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, from the second equation:                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8 - r)^2 + (y1 - 8 + r)^2 = r^2                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Expand (y1 - 8 + r)^2:                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y1² - 2(8 - r)y1 + (8 - r)^2 + (8 - r)^2 = r^2          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let me do that step again.                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, (8 - r)^2 + (y1 - (8 - r))^2 = r^2                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So:                                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (8 - r)^2 + (y1 -8 + r)^2 = r^2                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Expanding both terms:                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (64 - 16r + r²) + (y1² - 2(8 - r)y1 + (8 - r)^2) = r^2  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, expanding (y1 -8 + r)^2:                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = y1² - 2(8 - r)y1 + (8 - r)^2                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So total equation:                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 64 - 16r + r² + y1² - 2(8 - r)y1 + (8 - r)^2 = r²       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 64 -16r + r² + y1² -16y1 + 2r y1 + 64 -16r + r² = r²    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Combine like terms:                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 64 + 64 = 128                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -16r -16r = -32r                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ r² + r² = 2r²                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + y1² -16y1 + 2r y1                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So:                                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 128 -32r + 2r² + y1² -16y1 + 2r y1 = r²                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Bring r² to the left:                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 128 -32r + 2r² - r² + y1² -16y1 + 2r y1 = 0             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 128 -32r + r² + y1² -16y1 + 2r y1 = 0                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ This seems complicated. Let's see if we can find a      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ relation between x1 and y1.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From the circle's center (r, 8 - r), the points (x1, 0) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and (8, y1) lie on the circle, so the line segment      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ between them is a chord of the circle. But we are told  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that this chord is actually the diameter of the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle. Wait, but in a circle, any chord can be a   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter of a semicircle (the semicircle being one of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the two possible). However, the length of this chord is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the diameter of the semicircle, which would be equal to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the length of the chord, which is not necessarily the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter of the full circle.                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, there's confusion here between the diameter of    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle and the diameter of the full circle. The │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ full circle has diameter 2r, but the semicircle in      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ question has a diameter which is a chord of the full    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ circle. So the length of this chord (the diameter of    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle) would be less than or equal to 2r.      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But in our problem, the semicircle is entirely within   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the square, and we need to maximize its diameter. So    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ maybe the maximum occurs when the diameter of the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is equal to the diameter of the full circle, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ meaning the semicircle is a half of the full circle.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But in that case, the semicircle's diameter would be    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2r, and the full circle's radius is r.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But in our case, the full circle is tangent to x=0 and  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y=8, so centered at (r, 8 - r) with radius r. If the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is half of this circle, then its diameter    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ would be the vertical or horizontal diameter. For       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ example, a horizontal diameter would go from (0, 8 - r) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to (2r, 8 - r), but the problem states the semicircle   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is contained in the square. If the semicircle is the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ upper half, then it would extend up to y = 8 - r + r =  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 8, which is the top side, so that's okay. But the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ horizontal diameter would have length 2r, and since the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center is at (r, 8 - r), the semicircle would extend    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from x=0 to x=2r. To be entirely within the square, we  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ need 2r ≤8 ⇒ r ≤4. Then the maximum diameter would be   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 8, same as before.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But the problem states that the maximum diameter is m - │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(n), which is less than 8, so this approach is      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ missing something.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, maybe the semicircle is not a half of    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the circle tangent to x=0 and y=8, but rather a         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ different semicircle whose diameter is not aligned with │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the axes.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps the maximal diameter occurs when the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle touches the top, left, and bottom sides?     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let's consider that.                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If the semicircle is tangent to the top, left, and      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ bottom sides, then the center of the circle must be at  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (r, r), with radius r, because distance to left side    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ x=0 is r, distance to bottom y=0 is r, and distance to  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ top y=8 is 8 - r. Wait, but if it's tangent to top,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ left, and bottom, then the distances to left and bottom │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ are r, and distance to top is 8 - r. For the circle to  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be tangent to top, we need 8 - r = r ⇒ 8 = 2r ⇒ r =4.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So the center would be at (4,4), radius 4. Then the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle would be either the upper half or lower      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ half. If it's the upper half, it would go from (4,4) up │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to (4,8), but the diameter would be vertical from (4,0) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to (4,8), which is length 8. But again, this gives d=8, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is not the answer we need.                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Hmm. Maybe the semicircle is placed in a corner such    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that its diameter is at an angle, and it's tangent to   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ two sides. Let's consider the lower-left corner. Let’s  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ suppose the semicircle is tangent to the left side x=0  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and the bottom side y=0, with its diameter going from   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (a,0) to (0,b). The center is at (a/2, b/2), and the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ radius is sqrt( (a/2)^2 + (b/2)^2 ). The semicircle     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ must lie entirely within the square, so the circle's    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center must be at least radius away from the left and   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ bottom sides. Wait, but since it's tangent to x=0 and   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y=0, the distance from the center to x=0 is a/2 =       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ radius, and distance to y=0 is b/2 = radius. Therefore, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a/2 = b/2 ⇒ a = b. So radius r = sqrt( (a/2)^2 +        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (a/2)^2 ) = (a/2) sqrt(2). Therefore, a/2 = r /         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(2). But since a/2 = r, then r / sqrt(2) = r ⇒      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1/sqrt(2) =1, which is not possible. Wait, that can't   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be. There's a miscalculation here.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, if the semicircle is tangent to x=0 and y=0, then │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the distance from the center to each of these sides is  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equal to the radius. So if the center is at (r, r),     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then the distance to x=0 is r and the distance to y=0   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is r. The diameter would be a line segment of length    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2r, but where? If the semicircle is the upper half of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the circle centered at (r, r), then the diameter would  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be the horizontal line from (0, r) to (2r, r). But then │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle would be the upper half, which goes from │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y=r to y= r + r = 2r. To be entirely within the square, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2r ≤8 ⇒ r ≤4. Then the maximum diameter is 8, again.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But this still leads to d=8, which isn't the answer. So │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ maybe the maximum diameter isn't achieved by aligning   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle along the sides or in the corners, but   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ somewhere else.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps the semicircle is placed such that it     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ touches the midpoint of the top side and the midpoint   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of the right side, forming a diameter between (8,4) and │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (4,8), but then the semicircle would curve outside the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square. Hmm, not helpful.                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, maybe the maximum occurs when the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is inscribed in a corner, touching two       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ adjacent sides and passing through the opposite corner. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but the opposite corner is (8,8), and if the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle is touching, say, the left and bottom sides, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then the farthest it can reach is up to (8,8)? That     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ seems too far.                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's think differently. Suppose we have a        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle inside the square, not necessarily aligned   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ with any sides. The maximal diameter would be the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ longest possible line segment that can fit inside the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square with the semicircle arc also inside.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The longest line segment in a square is the diagonal,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is 8√2, but the semicircle over that diagonal     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ would have a radius of 4√2, which is about 5.656, but   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the semicircle would extend outside the square. So that │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ doesn't work.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, if we rotate the semicircle so that its  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ diameter is at some angle θ from the horizontal, then   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ perhaps we can fit a longer diameter before the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ semicircle arc hits the square's boundary.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ To model this, let's suppose the diameter is placed     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from point (a, 0) to (8, b), as before. The semicircle  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ must curve upwards and to the left, staying inside the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square. The highest point of the semicircle will be     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ important because it might hit the top side y=8, and    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the leftmost point might hit x=0. So perhaps the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ maximum diameter occurs when the semicircle is          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ simultaneously tangent to the top side y=8 and the left │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ side x=0.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let’s assume that the semicircle is tangent to x=0 and  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ y=8. Then, the center of the circle (which is also the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center of the semicircle's diameter) must be at (r, 8 - │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ r), where r is the radius. Wait, but this is similar to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ earlier thoughts.                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, if the circle is tangent to x=0 and y=8, its      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ center is at (r, 8 - r), radius r. Then, the diameter   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of the semicircle must be a chord of this circle. The   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ endpoints of the diameter are (a, 0) and (8, b). These  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ points must lie on the circle.                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, substituting (a, 0) into the circle equation:       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (a - r)^2 + (0 - (8 - r))^2 = r^2                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ => (a - r)^2 + (8 - r)^2 = r^2                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, substituting (8, b):                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
