│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Again, as a fraction, 287/4 is 71 3/4.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Then, plug d into equation (C):                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 16*(287/4) + e = 566                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 16*(287)/4 simplifies to 4*287 = 1148                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, 1148 + e = 566                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, e = 566 - 1148 = -582                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, e is -582.                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, Q(x) is -2x² + (287/4)x -582.                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, now, I need to compute P(0) + Q(0). Since P(x) is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2x² - (289/4)x + 698, P(0) is the constant term, 698.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, Q(x) is -2x² + (287/4)x -582, so Q(0) is     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -582.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, P(0) + Q(0) = 698 + (-582) = 116.            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, that seems straightforward. Let me verify.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Yes, P(0) is the constant term, and Q(0) is the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ constant term. So adding them directly gives 698 - 582  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = 116.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, the answer is 116.                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But just to make sure I didn't make any arithmetic      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ mistakes, let me double-check.                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For P(0), the constant term is c which we found to be   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 698.                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For Q(x), the constant term is e which we found to be   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -582.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 698 + (-582) = 116.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Everything seems to add up correctly. So, I think       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that's the answer.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ **Final Answer**                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \boxed{116}                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ </think>                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given two quadratic polynomials \( P(x) \) and \( Q(x)  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \) with leading coefficients 2 and -2, respectively,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and both passing through the points \((16, 54)\) and    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \((20, 53)\). We need to find \( P(0) + Q(0) \).        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, we write the general forms of the polynomials:   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( P(x) = 2x^2 + bx + c \)                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( Q(x) = -2x^2 + dx + e \)                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Using the points \((16, 54)\) and \((20, 53)\), we set  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ up the following equations for \( P(x) \):              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. \( 2(16)^2 + 16b + c = 54 \)                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2. \( 2(20)^2 + 20b + c = 53 \)                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Calculating these, we get:                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. \( 512 + 16b + c = 54 \) which simplifies to \( 16b  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + c = -458 \)                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2. \( 800 + 20b + c = 53 \) which simplifies to \( 20b  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + c = -747 \)                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Subtracting the first equation from the second:         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ (20b + c) - (16b + c) = -747 - (-458) \]             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ 4b = -289 \]                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ b = -72.25 \]                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Substituting \( b \) back into \( 16b + c = -458 \):    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ 16(-72.25) + c = -458 \]                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ -1156 + c = -458 \]                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ c = 698 \]                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, \( P(x) = 2x^2 - 72.25x + 698 \).                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Next, using the points \((16, 54)\) and \((20, 53)\)    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ for \( Q(x) \):                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( Q(16) = -2(16)^2 + 16d + e = 54 \)                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( Q(20) = -2(20)^2 + 20d + e = 53 \)                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Calculating these, we get:                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. \( -512 + 16d + e = 54 \) which simplifies to \( 16d │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + e = 566 \)                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2. \( -800 + 20d + e = 53 \) which simplifies to \( 20d │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + e = 853 \)                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Subtracting the first equation from the second:         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ (20d + e) - (16d + e) = 853 - 566 \]                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ 4d = 287 \]                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ d = 71.75 \]                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Substituting \( d \) back into \( 16d + e = 566 \):     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ 16(71.75) + e = 566 \]                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ 1148 + e = 566 \]                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[ e = -582 \]                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, \( Q(x) = -2x^2 + 71.75x - 582 \).                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Finally, we find \( P(0) + Q(0) \):                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( P(0) = 698 \)                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \( Q(0) = -582 \)                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, \( P(0) + Q(0) = 698 - 582 = 116 \).         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \boxed{116}                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \]                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼──────────────────────┼────────────────────┤ │
│ │ <｜begin▁of▁sentence｜>You are a helpful AI Assistant   │ Okay, so I need to find P(0) + Q(0) where P and Q are   │                 1.50 │               1.00 │ │
│ │ that provides well-reasoned and detailed responses. You │ quadratic polynomials. Their leading coefficients are 2 │                      │                    │ │
│ │ first think about the reasoning process as an internal  │ and -2 respectively, and both pass through the points   │                      │                    │ │
│ │ monologue and then output the final answer within       │ (16,54) and (20,53). Let me start by recalling that a   │                      │                    │ │
│ │ \boxed{}. Respond in the following format: <think>      │ quadratic polynomial has the general form ax² + bx + c. │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...                                                     │ So, for P(x), the leading coefficient is 2, which means │                      │                    │ │
│ │ </think>                                                │ P(x) = 2x² + b_p x + c_p. Similarly, Q(x) has a leading │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...\boxed{}<｜User｜>Quadratic polynomials $P(x)$ and   │ coefficient of -2, so Q(x) = -2x² + b_q x + c_q.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │ $Q(x)$ have leading coefficients $2$ and $-2,$          │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │ respectively. The graphs of both polynomials pass       │ Now, both polynomials pass through (16,54) and (20,53). │                      │                    │ │
│ │ through the two points $(16,54)$ and $(20,53).$ Find    │ That means when x is 16, P(16)=54 and Q(16)=54, and     │                      │                    │ │
│ │ $P(0) + Q(0).$<｜Assistant｜>                           │ when x is 20, P(20)=53 and Q(20)=53. That gives us four │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equations in total. Since each quadratic has three      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ coefficients (a, b, c), but the leading coefficients a  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ are given, so we need to find b and c for both P and Q. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │

│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │

│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │

│ │                                                         │ equals 54. So,                                          │                      │                    │ │

│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │

│ │                                                         │ For P(16) =54:                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 16b_p +c_p=54 -2*(16)^2 =54 -512= -458                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So equation 1: 16b_p +c_p= -458                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For P(20)=53:                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Give 20b_p +c_p=53 -2*(20)^2=53 -800= -747              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, two equations:                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. 16b_p +c_p = -458                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2. 20b_p +c_p = -747                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Subtracting equation1 from equation2 gives 4b_p= -289   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Hence, b_p= -289/4. Then, equation1: c_p= -458 -16b_p.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Plugging b_p in, c_p= -458 -16*(-289/4)= -458 +         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (16*289)/4.                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Compute numerator first: 16*289. 16* 289:               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 16*200=3200, 16*80=1280, 16*9=144:                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 3200+1280=4480+144=4624.                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So 4624 divided by 4=1156. Hence, c_p= -458             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ +1156=1156-458=698.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Ah, so earlier I thought c_p was 700, but it's          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ calculation is actually 698. So previous                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ miscalculation. So then c_p=698, not 700.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, for Q:                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For c_q=566 -16b_q.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Where b_q=287/4 as per before. So earlier mistake:      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For Q(16) equation:16b_q +c_q=566.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ once b_q is known: after solved b_q=287/4,              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c_q=566 -16*(287/4). Which is 566 - (16/4)*287=566      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -4*287=566 -1148= -582                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Yes, so that's correct. So the mistake was in the first │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ step for P's c_p: computing 1156-458 as 700, but it is  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1156-458=698. So that was my error! So critical         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ miscalculation here.                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ That affects both the computations. Therefore, in       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ conclusion P(0)=698 and Q(0)=c_q=-582. Therefore sum is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 698 -582=116.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait 698-582. Let's compute 582 from 700 subtract:  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 700-582=118. So 698 is two less than 700. So 118 minus  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ two:116. So 116 is the answer. So which is different    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from initial thought.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, there was a miscalculation here. Need to fix │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that. So indeed, I need to compute:                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ P(x)=2x² + (-289/4)x +698.                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Likewise verify: if I plug x=16 into P(x). 2*256=512.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (-289/4)*16= as above, which was -1156. Total then 512  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -1156 +698=512-1156= -644 +698=54! Which matches.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Because 698-644=54.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Well, slight indeterminate off. Whereas if calculated   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ as 512 -1156 +698 computes as                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (512+698)-1156=1210-1156=54 correct.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, when I plug x=20:                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2*(400)=800. (-289/4)*20= (-289/4)*20= (-289)*5= -1445. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So 800 -1445 +698=800+698=1498, 1498 -1445=53, which is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ correct.                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, P(x) c_p=698. So P(0)=698. Similarly, Q(0)=  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c_q= -582. So 698 + (-582)=116.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But hold on, adding -582: 698-582=116. That's correct.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Make sure that Q's c_q is actually in the equations.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Plugging into Q's equation to check. For Q(16):         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Q(x)= -2x² + (287/4)x + (-582).                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At x=16:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -2*(256)= -512. (287/4)*16= 287*4=1148. Wait, because   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 16 divided by 4 is 4. So 287*(4)=1148. So middle term   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is 1148. Then total -512 +1148 -582= -512 + (1148       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ -582)= -512 +566=54. Correct.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At x=20: Q(x) is -2*400= -800. (287/4)*20=287*(5)=1435. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So -800 +1435 -582=-800+ (1435 -582)= -800 +853=53.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Correct. Okay, that checks out.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, their constants when x=0, P(0)=698, Q(0)=-582. So   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ answer is 698 +(-582)=116. So final answer: 116. That's │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 698 -582=116.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But to confirm again:                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 698 minus 582:                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Start from 698                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Minus 500: 198                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Remains 582 has 500 +82.                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So 698 -500=198, then 198-82=116.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Yes, correct. So answer is 116.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Hence, I need to check that initial step where I        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ miscalculated 1156 -458 as 700. That was incorrect,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ actually, 1156-458 is 698. So the key difference here.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, final answer is 116.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ **Final Answer**                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \boxed{116}                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼──────────────────────┼────────────────────┤ │
│ │ <｜begin▁of▁sentence｜>You are a helpful AI Assistant   │ <think>                                                 │                 0.00 │               1.00 │ │
│ │ that provides well-reasoned and detailed responses. You │ Okay, so I've got this probability problem to solve.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │ first think about the reasoning process as an internal  │ Let me try to wrap my head around it step by step. The  │                      │                    │ │
│ │ monologue and then output the final answer within       │ problem says:                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │ \boxed{}. Respond in the following format: <think>      │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...                                                     │ Misha is rolling a standard six-sided die until she     │                      │                    │ │
│ │ </think>                                                │ rolls 1, then 2, then 3 in that specific order on three │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...\boxed{}<｜User｜>Misha rolls a standard, fair       │ consecutive rolls. We need to find the probability that │                      │                    │ │
│ │ six-sided die until she rolls 1-2-3 in that order on    │ she will roll the die an odd number of times. The       │                      │                    │ │
│ │ three consecutive rolls. The probability that she will  │ answer should be in the form of a fraction m/n, where m │                      │                    │ │
│ │ roll the die an odd number of times is $\dfrac{m}{n}$   │ and n are coprime, and then find m + n.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │ integers. Find $m+n$ .<｜Assistant｜>                   │ Hmm, okay. Let me break this down. So Misha is rolling  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a die repeatedly until she gets 1, then 2, then 3       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ consecutively. We need to calculate the probability     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that the number of rolls she makes is odd. That is, she │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ stops rolling after an odd number of times, and we need │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to find the probability of that happening.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, I need to model this situation. It sounds like a │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Markov process where each state represents the progress │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ towards rolling 1, then 2, then 3. So, the states can   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be:                                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - State A: No progress or the state before rolling the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ first number.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - State B: The state after rolling a 1.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - State C: The state after rolling a 1 and then a 2.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - State D: The state after rolling a 1, 2, and 3.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ That's the absorbing state where she stops.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Our goal is to find the probability that she reaches    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ State D on an odd number of steps.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me denote the probability of being absorbed at      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ State D on an odd number of steps starting from State A │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ as P_A, and similarly P_B and P_C.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, our initial state is State A, and Misha starts      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rolling. We need to find P_A.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From State A, when she rolls a 1, she moves to State B. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If she rolls anything else, she stays in State A. From  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ State B, rolling a 2 moves her to State C, and any      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ other roll keeps her in State B. From State C, she has  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ already rolled 1, 2, and 3, so she stops, and the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls is 3, which is odd, so she contributes  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1 to her probability.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but hold on. If she reaches State C, she stops    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ immediately on her third roll. So, the number of rolls  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is 3, which is odd. So, the probability for starting    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from State C is 1 for an odd number of rolls.           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But let's think about the process step by step.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From State A:                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll 1: probability 1/6, move to State B.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll not 1: probability 5/6, stay in State A.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, after the first roll, she can be in State A or B.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From State B:                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll 2: probability 1/6, move to State C.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll not 2: probability 5/6, stay in State B.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From State C:                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - She has already achieved the sequence, so the number  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of rolls is 3, which is odd. So, the probability of     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ stopping at odd is 1.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, we can model this with recursive equations.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me define:                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - P_A: Probability of stopping at odd rolls starting    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from State A.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - P_B: Probability of stopping at odd rolls starting    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from State B.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - P_C: Probability of stopping at odd rolls starting    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from State C.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We have P_C = 1, because she stops immediately on the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ third roll, which is odd.                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, let's write equations for P_A and P_B.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Starting from State A:                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - With probability 1/6, she moves to State B. Then, the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls increases by 1, and we have to consider │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the parity. If she was in State A, now at State B, the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls is 1 more, so the parity flips.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - With probability 5/6, she stays in State A, so the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls is 1 more, parity flips.                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but I need the probability of stopping at an odd  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls. So, starting from A, she can go to B   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ or stay in A. Similarly from B.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me think more carefully. Let's denote:              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At State A: she hasn't got 1 yet. She can:              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll 1: probability 1/6, move to State B, and now the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls is 1 (odd).                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - Roll not 1: probability 5/6, stay in State A, number  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of rolls is 1 (odd).                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no. Wait, the number of rolls is 1, which is odd. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, if she gets to State A again, the number of rolls   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is still odd.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But we're interested in the parity. So, it's about the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls, not the state.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me think differently. Let's model the parity.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Each time she rolls, the number of rolls increases by   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. So, after each roll, the parity flips.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But she stops when she reaches State C.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, maybe it's better to model it as a state machine  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ with transitions, considering whether the current roll  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ makes her progress towards State C or not.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, perhaps it's better to define P_A and    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ P_B as the probabilities starting from State A and B,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ respectively, of stopping at an odd number of rolls.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, starting from A:                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - If she rolls 1 (prob 1/6), she moves to B. Then, from │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ B, she has some probability to end on odd or even.      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - If she doesn't roll 1 (prob 5/6), she stays in A, and │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the number of rolls is still odd.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, starting from B:                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - If she rolls 2 (prob 1/6), she moves to C, which ends │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the process on an odd count (since the total rolls are  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 3: 1 from A, 1 from B, 1 from C). So, this contributes  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1 to the probability.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - If she doesn't roll 2 (prob 5/6), she stays in B, and │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the number of rolls is still odd + 1, which is even.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps not. Let me clarify.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me define:                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ After starting in State A, she makes a roll. If she     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rolls a 1, she proceeds to State B. The number of rolls │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is now 1 (odd). Then, from State B, she makes another   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ roll. If she rolls a 2, she proceeds to State C, which  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is the end. The total number of rolls is 1 (from A) + 1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (from B) + 1 (from C) = 3, which is odd, so this        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ contributes to the probability.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If she doesn't roll 2 from State B, she stays in State  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ B, and the number of rolls is 1 (odd) + 0 (since she    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ didn't move) = 1 (odd). So, from State B, if she        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ doesn't roll a 2, the parity is still odd.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, she's making another roll, but the number of  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rolls is still odd (1 + 1 = 2, but since she's moving   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ again, it's 1 + 1 = 2, but we are concerned with parity │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ after each roll). Maybe I need to model it differently. │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Alternatively, perhaps I can represent the probability  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of ending on an odd number of rolls from each state by  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ considering transitions.                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me try to formalize this.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let P_A be the probability of stopping at odd rolls     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ starting from A.                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From A:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - 1/6 chance to move to B, and then from B, the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability is P_B.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - 5/6 chance to stay in A, so from A, the probability   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is P_A.                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, P_A = (1/6)*P_B + (5/6)*P_A.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, P_B can be defined as:                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From B:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - 1/6 chance to move to C, which ends the process,      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ contributing 1 to the probability.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - 5/6 chance to stay in B, so the probability is P_B.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, P_B = (1/6)*1 + (5/6)*P_B.                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, P_C would be the probability of stopping at  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ odd rolls starting from C, which is 1, because she      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ stops on an odd number of rolls (3). So, P_C = 1.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, we have the equations:                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1. P_A = (1/6)*P_B + (5/6)*P_A                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2. P_B = (1/6)*1 + (5/6)*P_B                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 3. P_C = 1                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me solve equation 2 for P_B.                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Equation 2: P_B = (1/6) + (5/6)P_B                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Subtract (5/6)P_B from both sides:                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ P_B - (5/6)P_B = 1/6                                    │                      │                    │ │
