│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's re-examine the equation from S0:            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0, the probability of being absorbed at S3 at     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ even step is f_E.                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0 at even step, with probability 1/6, go to S1,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which at even step (but next step is odd) can be        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed at S3 with probability f_O.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, f_O is the absorption probability at S3 on    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ odd steps from S0.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I'm mixing up.                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, f_E is the probability of being absorbed at S3 on │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ even steps, starting from S0.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, starting from S0, f_E is the probability of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ being absorbed at S3 at even steps, which would be the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of being absorbed at S3 at step 1, 3, 5,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ etc.                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, this is getting too confusing. Maybe I should     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ look for another approach.                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I can consider that the probability of    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ being absorbed at S3 on an odd step is equal to the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability that, after an even number of steps, we are │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ in S0 and then move to S1, and then proceed towards S3  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ on an odd step.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps it's better to model it using the number  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of steps taken modulo 2.                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me define a_n as the probability of being in S0 at  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ step n, b_n as in S1, c_n as in S2, and d_n as being    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed at S3.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We need to find the sum of d_n over odd n, starting     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from d_0 = 0.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The recurrence relations are:                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a_{n+1} = (5/6)*a_n + (1/6)*b_n                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ b_{n+1} = (1/6)*a_n + (1/6)*b_n + (1/6)*c_n             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c_{n+1} = (1/6)*b_n + (4/6)*c_n                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d_{n+1} = (1/6)*c_n                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The initial conditions are a_0 = 1, b_0 = c_0 = d_0 =   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, we can compute the probabilities step by step.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me compute the first few steps to see if a pattern  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ emerges.                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=0:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a0 = 1, b0 = c0 = d0 = 0                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=1:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a1 = (5/6)*1 + (1/6)*0 = 5/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ b1 = (1/6)*1 + (1/6)*0 + (1/6)*0 = 1/6                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c1 = (1/6)*0 + (4/6)*0 = 0                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d1 = (1/6)*0 = 0                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=2:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a2 = (5/6)*(5/6) + (1/6)*(1/6) = 25/36 + 1/36 = 26/36 = │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 13/18                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ b2 = (1/6)*(5/6) + (1/6)*(1/6) + (1/6)*0 = 5/36 + 1/36  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = 6/36 = 1/6                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c2 = (1/6)*(1/6) + (4/6)*0 = 1/36                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d2 = (1/6)*(1/6) = 1/36                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=3:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a3 = (5/6)*(13/18) + (1/6)*(1/6) = 65/108 + 1/36 =      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 65/108 + 3/108 = 68/108 = 34/54 = 17/27                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ b3 = (1/6)*(13/18) + (1/6)*(1/6) + (1/6)*(1/36) =       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 13/108 + 1/36 + 1/216 = 26/216 + 6/216 + 1/216 = 33/216 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = 11/72                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c3 = (1/6)*(1/6) + (4/6)*(1/36) = 1/36 + 4/216 = 6/216  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + 4/216 = 10/216 = 5/108                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d3 = (1/6)*(5/108) = 5/648                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=4:                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a4 = (5/6)*(17/27) + (1/6)*(11/72) = 85/162 + 11/432 =  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (85*2.666...)/432 + 11/432 ≈ Not sure, let me compute   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ exact fractions.                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Convert to a common denominator, say 432.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 85/162 = (85*2.666...)/432 = (85*8)/432 = 680/432       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, 162*2.666=432, so 85/162 = (85*2.666)/432,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but this is messy. Maybe convert to decimals.           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Compute 85/162 ≈ 0.5246 and 11/432 ≈ 0.0252             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, a4 ≈ 0.5246 + 0.0252 ≈ 0.5498                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, b4 = (1/6)*(17/27) + (1/6)*(1/6) +           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1/6)*(1/108) ≈ 0.0555 + 0.0278 + 0.0016 ≈ 0.0849       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c4 = (1/6)*(11/72) + (4/6)*(5/108) ≈ 0.0278 + 0.1667 ≈  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.1945                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ d4 = (1/6)*c4 ≈ (1/6)*0.1945 ≈ 0.0324                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Hmm, this is getting complicated. Maybe I can find a    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ pattern or a simpler way.                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, looking at the values:                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ At n=0: d0 = 0                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ n=1: d1=0                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ n=2: d2=1/36                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ n=3: d3=5/648                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ n=4: d4≈0.0324                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ This seems to be decreasing, but I'm not sure if it's   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ converging to zero or something else.                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but I'm supposed to find the probability of being │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed at S3 on an odd step, so it's the sum of d_n   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ over odd n.                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From the above, d1=0, d3=5/648, d5 would be smaller,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ etc.                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but this approach might not be practical. I need  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a better way.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I can model the problem using the concept │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of the probability generating function for the parity.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, alternatively, maybe I can consider that the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of steps to get S3 is a geometric distribution,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but considering the parity.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, another idea: since the target is 1-2-3, the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of success on each trial is 1/6. The number │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of trials until success is geometric with p=1/6.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But we need the probability that the number of trials   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is odd.                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, for a geometric distribution starting at t=1, the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability that t is odd is (1 - p)/p if p=1/2, but    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ not sure if that applies here.                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, for a geometric distribution with support on  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ {1,2,3,...}, the probability that t is odd is           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sum_{k=0}^\infty (1/6)(5/6)^{2k+1} = (1/6)(5/6)         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sum_{k=0}^\infty (25/36)^k = (5/36) * (1 / (1 - 25/36)) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = (5/36) * (36/11) = 5/11.                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, this is from the expectation that the probability │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of success on an odd trial is (p)/(1 - p), but I'm not  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sure.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let me verify.                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The probability that the first success occurs on an odd │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ trial is:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Sum_{k=0}^\infty (1 - p)^{2k} * p * (1/2)^{2k+1}? No,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that's not correct.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, actually, the probability that the first success  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ occurs on an odd trial is sum_{k=0}^\infty (1 - p)^{2k} │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ * p * (1/2), but this is not accurate.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let me think again.                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The probability that the first success is at trial t,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ where t is odd.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ This is equal to sum_{k=0}^\infty (1 - p)^{2k} * p,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ since t=2k+1.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, the sum is p * sum_{k=0}^\infty [(1 - p)^2]^k = p / │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - (1 - p)^2) ) = p / (2p - p^2) = 1 / (2 - p).       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Substituting p=1/6, we get 1 / (2 - 1/6) = 1 / (11/6) = │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 6/11.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, so the probability that the first success is on   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ an odd trial is 6/11.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait, this is only for the first success, but our   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ problem is about succeeding on a three-letter sequence, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ not just one letter.                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, so perhaps I need to extend this reasoning.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but in our case, the target is 1-2-3, so it's a   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ three-letter sequence, not just one letter.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, the probability of success on each trial is still   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1/6, but the trials are not independent in terms of the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sequence.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ This complicates things because the trials are          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ dependent on the previous trials.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I can model this as a Markov chain with   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ states corresponding to the progress towards the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ target.                                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me define the states as:                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S0: starting state                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S1: progress to 1                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S2: progress to 1-2                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S3: success state (absorbing)                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Then, the transition matrix Q is:                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S1 with probability 1/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S0 with probability 5/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S1:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S2 with probability 1/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S1 with probability 1/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S0 with probability 4/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S2:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S3 with probability 1/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S2 with probability 1/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - To S0 with probability 4/6                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We can set up the system of equations for the           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorption probabilities:                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let f_O be the probability of being absorbed at S3 on   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ an odd step.                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let f_E be the probability of being absorbed at S3 on   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ an even step.                                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We can write the following equations:                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E = (1/6)*f_O + (5/6)*f_E                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S1:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E = (1/6)*f_O + (4/6)*f_E                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S2:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E = (1/6)*f_O + (4/6)*f_E                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but this leads to f_E = f_O, which is not         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ possible because we're looking for f_O.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I made a mistake in setting up the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equations.                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps in the equations, I should consider that  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ after being absorbed at S3, the process stops, and we   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ add the absorption probability accordingly.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let me try setting up the equations differently.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me define:                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0, the probability of being absorbed at S3 on an  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ odd step is f_O.                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0, the probability of being absorbed at S3 on an  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ even step is f_E.                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, from S1, the probability of being absorbed   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ at S3 on an odd step is f_O1, and on an even step is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E1.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S2, the probability is f_O2 and f_E2.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But this might get too complicated.                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I can consider that once we reach S3, the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ process stops, so the absorption probabilities are      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ fixed.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, f_O is the probability that starting from S0, the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ process is absorbed at S3 on an odd step.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, f_E is the probability of absorption on an   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ even step.                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We can write the following equations:                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_O = (1/6)*f_O + (5/6)*f_E + p_0                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, p_0 is the probability of being absorbed at S3    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from S0. But S0 doesn't absorb at S3, so p_0=0.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, absorption occurs when the sequence is 1-2-3, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ starting from S0, so the first absorption is at S1, not │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S3.                                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, absorption at S3 occurs only when the sequence is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ exactly 1-2-3, so from S0, the first absorption is at   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S1, not S3.                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I'm misunderstanding the definition of    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorption.                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, in the context of the problem, once you reach S3, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ you stop, so absorption occurs at S3. So, the           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorption probabilities are the probabilities of being │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed at S3 at even or odd steps.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, the probability of being absorbed at S3 on an odd │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ step is f_O, and on an even step is f_E.                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, f_O + f_E = 1, since from any state, the process    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ must be absorbed eventually.                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but starting from S0, the probability of being    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed at S3 on an odd step is f_O, and on an even    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ step is f_E.                                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, f_O + f_E = 1.                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, setting up the equations based on transitions:     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_O = (1/6)*f_O + (5/6)*f_E + p_0, where p_0 is the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of being absorbed at S3 from S0. But once   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ you reach S0 again, you can't reach S3 directly, so     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ p_0=0.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, absorption occurs when the sequence is        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ exactly 1-2-3, so once you reach S3, you stop, so from  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ S0, the first absorption is at S1, not S3.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, I'm getting confused. Let me clarify.             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ In this problem, each roll advances the progress        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ towards the target sequence. Once the target sequence   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is achieved, the process stops.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, S0 is the start state, S1 is one progress, S2 is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ two progress, and S3 is success.                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, from S0, if you roll 1, you go to S1, else stay   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ at S0.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S1, if you roll 2, you go to S2, else stay at S1   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ or move to S0.                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S2, if you roll 3, you go to S3, else stay at S2   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ or move to S0.                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, the absorption occurs at S3.                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, starting from S0, the probability of being absorbed │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ at S3 on an odd step is f_O, and on an even step is     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E.                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, the total absorption probability is f_O + f_E.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait, the problem asks for the probability that the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ number of rolls is odd, regardless of whether it's      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed or not. Wait, no, the process stops when it's  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorbed, so the number of rolls is fixed.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, no, in this problem, the number of rolls is       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ variable until the sequence is achieved. So, we need to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ find the probability that the number of rolls is odd,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ starting from S0.                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but in reality, starting from S0, the number of   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rolls is variable, and we need the probability that     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ it's odd.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps I can model the problem as a Markov chain │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ with states S0, S1, S2, S3, and compute the absorption  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probabilities at S3 on even and odd steps.              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But I think I'm going in circles. Maybe I should look   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ for another approach.                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, another idea: the probability that the number of  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ trials until the first success (which is the target     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sequence 1-2-3) is odd can be calculated using the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ formula for the probability of the first success at an  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ odd trial.                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For a geometric distribution, the probability of the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ first success on the n-th trial is p*(1-p)^{n-1}.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The probability that n is odd is sum_{k=0}^\infty       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ p*(1-p)^{2k} = p / (1 - (1-p)^2) ) = p / (2p - p^2) = 1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ / (2 - p).                                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ For p=1/6, this would be 1 / (2 - 1/6) = 1 / (11/6) =   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 6/11.                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But this is the probability that the first success      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ occurs on an odd trial.                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But in our problem, the first success is the first      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ occurrence of the target sequence, which is longer than │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ just a single letter. So, this approach might not       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ directly apply.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but perhaps we can extend it. Since the target    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sequence is 1-2-3, which is three letters, the          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of success on each trial is 1/6, and the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ trials are independent in terms of the sequence.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but the trials are not independent because once   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ you reach 1-2, the next roll determines if you get to   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1-2-3.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, perhaps it's better to model the problem as a     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Markov chain and compute the absorption probabilities   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ at an odd step.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But I need to find a way to compute the absorption      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probabilities at odd steps.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, another idea: the probability that the number of  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rolls is odd is equal to the sum over all odd n of the  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of being absorbed at S3 on the n-th trial.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, the probability of being absorbed at S3 on   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ an even trial is the sum over all even n of the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ absorption probability at S3 on the n-th trial.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If I can compute these sums, I can find f_O and f_E,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then f_O is the desired probability.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, since we're dealing with an absorbing Markov       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ chain, I can use the formula:                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_O = sum_{n odd} P(reach S3 on n-th trial and n is     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ odd)                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, f_E = sum_{n even} P(reach S3 on n-th trial  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and n is even)                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But I need to find a way to sum these probabilities.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From the theory of absorbing Markov chains, the         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ probability of being absorbed at a specific state can   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be found using the fundamental matrix.                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But I think this is getting too advanced, and perhaps I │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ should look for another approach.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, going back to the earlier equations, I can try to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ solve them.                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S0:                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E = (1/6)*f_O + (5/6)*f_E + 0                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ From S1 and S2:                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E = (1/6)*f_O + (4/6)*f_E                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, solving from S0:                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ f_E - (5/6)f_E = (1/6)f_O                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1/6)f_E = (1/6)f_O                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, f_E = f_O                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But this can't be right, because f_O + f_E = 1, so f_O  │                      │                    │ │
