│ │                                                         │ s, 0), and moving up s units to (1, s). But then, the   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square would have vertices at B(1,0), G(1, s), H(1 + s, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ s), and C(1 + s, 0).                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But if that's the case, then point G(1, s) must lie on  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ AE, and point H(1 + s, s) must lie on AE as well? Wait, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ no, only the vertex G is on AE. Wait, the problem says  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ "a square with vertex B has sides that are parallel to  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ those of ABCD and a vertex on AE." So, only one vertex  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is on AE, which is G(1, s). The other vertices, C and   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ H, are not necessarily on AE.                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, only G is on AE. Therefore, point G(1, s) is on AE, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ so s = (2 - sqrt(3)), as earlier.                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But also, the square's side length is s, so from B(1,0) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to G(1, s) is s units up. But then, from G(1, s) to H(1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + s, s) is rightward s units. But point H is (1 + s,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ s), but the next square would need to have another      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex, which is H. But we don't care about H           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ necessarily being on AE, just G.                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, the side length of the smaller square is s = 2 -    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(3). But wait, 2 - sqrt(3) is approximately 0.2679, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is positive and less than 1, so it's valid.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But in the problem statement, it's given that the side  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ length is (a - sqrt(b))/c, which is (2 - sqrt(3))/1, so │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a=2, b=3, c=1, so a + b + c = 2 + 3 + 1 = 6.            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but let me verify this because sometimes we might │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ have made a miscalculation. Let's double-check.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We found k = 2 - sqrt(3). Then, the side length s is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equal to k, so s = 2 - sqrt(3). So, yes, the side       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ length is (2 - sqrt(3))/1, so a=2, b=3, c=1, so a + b + │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c = 6.                                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, the answer is 6.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait, let me think again. If the square extends     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from B(1,0) up to (1, s), and right to (1 + s, 0), then │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the other vertices are C(1 + s, 0) and H(1 + s, s). But │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the problem only mentions that one vertex is on AE,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is G(1, s). So, as long as G is on AE, the square │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is valid.                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But let me confirm if G is indeed on AE. The equation   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of AE is y = (2 - sqrt(3))x. At x=1, y = 2 - sqrt(3).   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So, G(1, s) must satisfy s = (2 - sqrt(3)) * 1, so s =  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2 - sqrt(3). So yes, that's correct.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, the side length is 2 - sqrt(3), so a=2, b=3, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ c=1, and a + b + c = 6.                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But wait, hold on. 2 - sqrt(3) is approximately 0.2679, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is positive. But when I look at the original      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square ABCD with side 1, the smaller square with side 2 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - sqrt(3) is indeed inside it.                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Yes, that makes sense. So, I think my final answer is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 6.                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ **Final Answer**                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \boxed{6}                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ </think>                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We start by assigning coordinates to the square         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(ABCD\) with vertices \(A(0,0)\), \(B(1,0)\),          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(C(1,1)\), and \(D(0,1)\). Points \(E\) and \(F\) are  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ on \(\overline{BC}\) and \(\overline{CD}\)              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ respectively, with coordinates \(E(1, e)\) and \(F(f,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1)\). Triangle \(AEF\) is equilateral, so \(AE = EF =   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ FA\).                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Using the distance formula, we find:                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \(AE = \sqrt{1 + e^2}\)                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \(EF = \sqrt{(f - 1)^2 + (1 - e)^2}\)                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - \(FA = \sqrt{f^2 + 1}\)                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Equating these distances, we find \(e = f = k\) where   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(k\) is between 0 and 1. Solving the quadratic         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equation, we get \(k = 2 - \sqrt{3}\).                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Next, we consider the smaller square with vertex        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(B(1,0)\) and sides parallel to \(ABCD\). The vertex   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(G(1, s)\) lies on \(AE\). The equation of line \(AE\) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is \(y = (2 - \sqrt{3})x\). Since \(s = 2 - \sqrt{3}\), │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the side length of the smaller square is \(2 -          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \sqrt{3}\).                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Thus, \(a = 2\), \(b = 3\), and \(c = 1\). Therefore,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \(a + b + c = 2 + 3 + 1 = 6\).                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \[                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \boxed{6}                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ \]                                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼──────────────────────┼────────────────────┤ │
│ │ <｜begin▁of▁sentence｜>You are a helpful AI Assistant   │ Okay, so I need to solve this geometry problem. Let me  │                 1.50 │               1.00 │ │
│ │ that provides well-reasoned and detailed responses. You │ first parse what's given and what needs to be found.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │ first think about the reasoning process as an internal  │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │ monologue and then output the final answer within       │ We have square ABCD with sides of length 1. Points E    │                      │                    │ │
│ │ \boxed{}. Respond in the following format: <think>      │ and F are on sides BC and CD, respectively, such that   │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...                                                     │ triangle AEF is equilateral. Then there's another       │                      │                    │ │
│ │ </think>                                                │ square with vertex B, whose sides are parallel to those │                      │                    │ │
│ │ ...\boxed{}<｜User｜>Square $ABCD$ has sides of length  │ of ABCD, and another vertex (let me assume it's the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │ 1. Points $E$ and $F$ are on $\overline{BC}$ and        │ opposite vertex from B) lies on AE. We need to find the │                      │                    │ │
│ │ $\overline{CD},$ respectively, so that $\triangle AEF$  │ side length of this smaller square, which is given in   │                      │                    │ │
│ │ is equilateral. A square with vertex $B$ has sides that │ the form (a - sqrt(b))/c, where a, b, c are positive    │                      │                    │ │
│ │ are parallel to those of $ABCD$ and a vertex on         │ integers, b square-free, and then compute a + b + c.    │                      │                    │ │
│ │ $\overline{AE}.$ The length of a side of this smaller   │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │ square is $\frac{a-\sqrt{b}}{c},$ where $a, b,$ and $c$ │ Alright, let me try to visualize this. Square ABCD. Let │                      │                    │ │
│ │ are positive integers and $b$ is not divisible by the   │ me label the square with coordinates to make it easier. │                      │                    │ │
│ │ square of any prime. Find $a+b+c.$<｜Assistant｜>       │ Let me place square ABCD with point A at the origin     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (0,0), B at (1,0), C at (1,1), D at (0,1). So sides AB, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ BC, CD, DA are along the axes.                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Points E is on BC and F is on CD. So E has coordinates  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1, y) for some y between 0 and 1, and F has            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ coordinates (x,1) for some x between 0 and 1. Wait,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ hold on: BC goes from (1,0) to (1,1), so actually, if E │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is on BC, then E is (1, t) where t is between 0 and 1.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Similarly, CD goes from (1,1) to (0,1), so F is on CD,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ so F is (s,1) where s is between 0 and 1.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but the problem states triangle AEF is            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equilateral. So points A (0,0), E (1, t), F (s,1). The  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ distances AE, EF, FA must all be equal.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, compute the distances:                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ AE: from (0,0) to (1, t). That distance is sqrt((1-0)^2 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ + (t - 0)^2) = sqrt(1 + t^2).                           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ AF: from (0,0) to (s,1). Distance sqrt((s)^2 + (1)^2) = │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(s^2 + 1).                                          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ EF: from (1, t) to (s,1). Distance sqrt((s - 1)^2 + (1  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - t)^2).                                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Since triangle AEF is equilateral, these three          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ distances must be equal. Therefore, set them equal:     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(1 + t^2) = sqrt(s^2 + 1) = sqrt((s - 1)^2 + (1 -   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t)^2)                                                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, equate the first two: sqrt(1 + t^2) = sqrt(1 +   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ s^2). Therefore, 1 + t^2 = 1 + s^2 => t^2 = s^2. Since  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t and s are between 0 and 1, this implies t = s.        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So s = t. Let's call this common variable t. So E is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1, t) and F is (t, 1).                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, set AE = EF. So sqrt(1 + t^2) = sqrt((t - 1)^2 +   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - t)^2).                                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Compute the right-hand side:                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt((t - 1)^2 + (1 - t)^2) = sqrt(2*(1 - t)^2) =       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(2)*|1 - t|. Since t is between 0 and 1, 1 - t is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ positive, so this is sqrt(2)*(1 - t).                   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, sqrt(1 + t^2) = sqrt(2)*(1 - t).             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Square both sides:                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1 + t^2 = 2*(1 - 2t + t^2)                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Expand the right-hand side:                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1 + t^2 = 2 - 4t + 2t^2                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Bring all terms to left-hand side:                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1 + t^2 - 2 + 4t - 2t^2 = 0                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Combine like terms:                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (-1) + 4t - t^2 = 0                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Multiply both sides by -1:                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t^2 - 4t + 1 = 0                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Solve this quadratic equation for t:                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t = [4 ± sqrt(16 - 4*1*1)]/2 = [4 ± sqrt(12)]/2 = [4 ±  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 2*sqrt(3)]/2 = 2 ± sqrt(3)                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Since t is between 0 and 1, we take the smaller         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ solution:                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t = 2 - sqrt(3). Approximately 2 - 1.732 = 0.2679,      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is between 0 and 1.                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, t = 2 - sqrt(3). So E is (1, 2 - sqrt(3))    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and F is (2 - sqrt(3), 1).                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Okay, so now we know the coordinates of E and F. Now,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ moving on to the next part.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ There's a square with vertex B (which is (1,0)), whose  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sides are parallel to ABCD, so the sides are horizontal │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and vertical. The square has vertex B, and another      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex on AE. We need to find the side length of this   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ smaller square.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let me try to imagine this. The square has vertex at B  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1,0), and since sides are parallel, the square can be  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ either expanding upwards and to the left, or downwards  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and to the left, but since the square is inside ABCD    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (since it's smaller and has vertex on AE, which is      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ inside ABCD), so it must be expanding upwards and to    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the left. Wait, but ABCD is the original square. Wait,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the problem says "a square with vertex B has sides that │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ are parallel to those of ABCD and a vertex on AE". So   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the square has vertex B and another vertex on AE. Since │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the sides are parallel, the square can be in one of two │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ positions: either extending to the left and up from B,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ or extending down and to the left. But since B is at    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1,0), and the square must lie within the plane, but    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the original square ABCD is from (0,0) to (1,1). If the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square extends down from B, it would go below the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ original square, which is not possible because AE is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ inside ABCD. Therefore, the square must extend upwards  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and to the left from B. So the square would have        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertices at B (1,0), then moving left along the x-axis  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to (1 - k, 0), then up to (1 - k, k), and then to (1,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ k), but wait, no. Wait, if the square is expanding      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ upwards and to the left with side length k, starting at │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ B (1,0), then the next vertex would be (1,0) moving     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ left k units to (1 - k, 0), then up k units to (1 - k,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ k), then right k units to (1, k). But the problem says  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ it's a square with vertex B and another vertex on AE.   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So perhaps the square is such that from B, it goes up   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and left, forming a square with side length s, such     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that the vertex opposite to B is on AE.                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, maybe better to assign coordinates. Let's let the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square have side length h. Since it's parallel to ABCD, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ its sides are horizontal and vertical. Starting from B  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1,0), moving left h units and up h units. So the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square would have vertices at B (1,0), (1 - h, 0), (1 - │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h, h), and (1, h). The fourth vertex is (1, h). Wait,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but the problem says "a square with vertex B has sides  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that are parallel to those of ABCD and a vertex on AE". │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So one of the vertices other than B is on AE. Which     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ one? The square has vertices at (1,0), (1 - h,0), (1 -  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h, h), (1, h). So the other vertices are (1 - h, 0), (1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - h, h), and (1, h). The problem states that one of     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ these is on AE.                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ We need to determine which vertex is on AE. Let's see.  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The line AE goes from A (0,0) to E (1, t), where t = 2  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - sqrt(3). The parametric equation of AE can be written │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ as (x, y) = (k, k*t), where k ranges from 0 to 1.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So any point on AE is of the form (k, k*t) for some k   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ between 0 and 1.                                        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Now, the other vertices of the square are (1 - h, 0),   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - h, h), (1, h). Let's check if these lie on AE.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ First, (1 - h, 0): For this to be on AE, there must be  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ a k such that 1 - h = k and 0 = k*t. But k*t = 0        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ implies k = 0 (since t ≠ 0), so 1 - h = 0 => h = 1. But │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the square with side length 1 would coincide with ABCD, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but the problem says it's a smaller square, so h must   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be less than 1. Therefore, (1 - h, 0) is not on AE      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ except when h = 1, which is invalid.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Next, (1, h): For this to be on AE, we have x = 1, so k │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ must be 1 (since x = k). Then y = k*t = t. Therefore,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1, h) is on AE only if h = t. But h is the side length │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of the square, which we need to find. However, if h =   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t, then the square would have vertices at (1,0), (1 -   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t, 0), (1 - t, t), (1, t). But is (1, t) on AE? Yes,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ because E is (1, t) and AE goes from (0,0) to (1, t).   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but in that case, the square's upper vertex is E  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ itself. But the problem states the square has vertex B  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and a vertex on AE. If h = t, then the square has       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex at E. But is E a vertex of the square? Let's     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ see: If the square has vertices at (1,0), (1 - t, 0),   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - t, t), (1, t), then yes, (1, t) is a vertex.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ However, in the problem statement, it's stated that the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square has vertex B and a vertex on AE, not necessarily │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ another vertex. So this might be a possibility. But in  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that case, the side length h would be t = 2 - sqrt(3).  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But let me check if this is correct.                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, if the square's side is t, then the square would  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ extend from (1,0) to (1 - t, 0) leftwards, and up to (1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - t, t), and back to (1, t). But is (1 - t, t) on AE?   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let's check. The point (1 - t, t). Since AE is          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ parametrized as (k, k*t). So if 1 - t = k, then t = k*t │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ => k = (1 - t)/t. But then y-coordinate should be k*t = │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - t)/t * t = 1 - t. But in the square's vertex (1 -  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t, t), the y-coordinate is t, so unless 1 - t = t,      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which would imply t = 0.5. But t is 2 - sqrt(3) ≈       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.2679, so 1 - t ≈ 0.7321 ≠ t. Therefore, (1 - t, t) is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ not on AE. Therefore, the only other vertex on AE is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1, t), which is E. But if the square has vertex at E,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then the square would have side length t, but as we     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ saw, the other vertex (1 - t, t) is not on AE. Wait,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but the problem states "a square with vertex B has      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sides that are parallel to those of ABCD and a vertex   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ on AE". It doesn't specify which vertex, just that one  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ of them is on AE. So if the square has vertex B (1,0)   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and another vertex (1, t) on AE, then the side length   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is t. But is that the square? Wait, if the square is    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ from (1,0) to (1, t), that's vertical, but squares have │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equal sides. Wait, no. Wait, if the square has side     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ length h, then from B (1,0), moving up h units would be │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1, h), and left h units would be (1 - h, 0). So the    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square is defined by (1,0), (1 - h, 0), (1 - h, h), (1, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h). So the four vertices. So among these, (1, h) is the │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ upper right vertex. If (1, h) is on AE, then h must     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equal t, because AE at x=1 is the point E (1, t).       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, h = t = 2 - sqrt(3). But 2 - sqrt(3) is      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ approximately 0.2679, so the square would have side     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ length 0.2679. But let me verify if that's correct.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, but if h = t, then the square's upper right       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ corner is at (1, h) = (1, t), which is point E. But in  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that case, the square would be from (1,0) to (1 - h, 0) │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ to (1 - h, h) to (1, h). So the square is attached to   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the right side of ABCD, but with upper vertex at E.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ However, in the original problem statement, it says "a  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square with vertex B has sides that are parallel to     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ those of ABCD and a vertex on AE". So if h = t, then    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ this satisfies the condition, as (1, h) is on AE. But   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is this the only possibility? Or could another vertex   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ be on AE?                                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's check the other vertex (1 - h, h). If that  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is on AE, then we have (1 - h, h) lying on AE, which is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ parametrized as (k, k*t). So 1 - h = k and h = k*t.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Then substituting k = 1 - h into the second equation: h │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ = (1 - h)*t. Therefore, h = t - h*t => h + h*t = t =>   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h(1 + t) = t => h = t/(1 + t). This would be another    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ possibility. So depending on which vertex is on AE, we  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ have two possibilities: either h = t or h = t/(1 + t).  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So we need to figure out which one is the case.         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But the problem says "a square with vertex B has sides  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that are parallel to those of ABCD and a vertex on AE". │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ It doesn't specify which vertex, so both possibilities  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ might exist. But likely, given that it's a smaller      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square, perhaps h = t/(1 + t) is smaller than h = t?    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Let's compute both.                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given t = 2 - sqrt(3) ≈ 0.2679,                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If h = t ≈ 0.2679,                                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h/(1 + t) ≈ 0.2679 / (1 + 0.2679) ≈ 0.2679 / 1.2679 ≈   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.211. So smaller. But is h = t/(1 + t) the correct     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ one?                                                    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, let's think geometrically. If we have the square  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ with vertex at B (1,0), and another vertex on AE. If    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the upper right vertex (1, h) is on AE, then h = t,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is approximately 0.2679. But this square would    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ extend from (1,0) to (1 - h,0) to (1 - h, h) to (1, h). │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The point (1, h) is E, which is on BC. But in the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ problem statement, the square is supposed to have a     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex on AE, not necessarily on BC. Wait, but E is on  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ BC and AE. So in that case, the square would have a     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex at E, which is on AE and BC. But maybe the       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ problem allows that. However, another square with       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex B, extending left and up, such that its upper    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ left vertex (1 - h, h) is on AE. Let me check that.     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ If (1 - h, h) is on AE, then as before, 1 - h = k, h =  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ k*t, so h = (1 - h)*t. Solving for h: h = t/(1 + t).    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given t = 2 - sqrt(3), then h = (2 - sqrt(3))/(1 + 2 -  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(3)) = (2 - sqrt(3))/(3 - sqrt(3)). Let me          │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ rationalize the denominator:                            │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Multiply numerator and denominator by (3 + sqrt(3)):    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ [(2 - sqrt(3))(3 + sqrt(3))]/[(3 - sqrt(3))(3 +         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(3))] = [6 + 2*sqrt(3) - 3*sqrt(3) -                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (sqrt(3))^2]/(9 - 3) =                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify numerator:                                     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 6 + 2*sqrt(3) - 3*sqrt(3) - 3 = (6 - 3) + (2*sqrt(3) -  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 3*sqrt(3)) = 3 - sqrt(3).                               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Denominator: 9 - 3 = 6.                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Therefore, h = (3 - sqrt(3))/6 = (3 - sqrt(3))/6.       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Simplify: h = (3 - sqrt(3))/6 = (3/6) - (sqrt(3)/6) =   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1/2) - (sqrt(3)/6) = (3 - sqrt(3))/6. Wait, same as    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ before. So h = (3 - sqrt(3))/6 ≈ (3 - 1.732)/6 ≈        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 1.268/6 ≈ 0.2113.                                       │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So h ≈ 0.2113. So this is smaller than h = t ≈ 0.2679,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is the other possibility.                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But which one is correct? Let's think. If the square    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ has vertex (1, h) on AE, then h = t, which is E, but E  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is on BC. However, the square with vertex (1, h) = E    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ would have side length h = t, but then the square would │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ extend from B (1,0) to E (1, t) vertically, but since   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the square must have sides parallel to ABCD, the        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ horizontal side would be from (1,0) to (1 - h, 0). So   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ if h = t ≈ 0.2679, then the square would extend left to │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1 - h, 0) ≈ (0.732, 0), and up to (1 - h, h) ≈ (0.732, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.2679). But point (1 - h, h) is (approx 0.732,         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.2679). Is this point on AE? Let's check. The line AE  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ goes from (0,0) to (1, t). So the slope is t/1 = t. The │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ equation of AE is y = t x.                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ So for the point (1 - h, h), plug into y = t x: h =     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t*(1 - h). Which is exactly the equation we had before, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ leading to h = t/(1 + t). Therefore, if (1 - h, h) is   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ on AE, then h = t/(1 + t). Therefore, if the square is  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ such that the upper left vertex (1 - h, h) is on AE,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then h = t/(1 + t). However, in the case where h = t,   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the upper right vertex (1, h) is on AE (since (1, h) is │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ E, which is on AE). So which one is it?                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ The problem states "a square with vertex B has sides    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ that are parallel to those of ABCD and a vertex on AE". │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ It doesn't specify which vertex. However, if h = t,     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ then the square has vertices at B (1,0), (1 - t, 0), (1 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ - t, t), (1, t). The vertex (1, t) is on AE and BC. The │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex (1 - t, t) is not on AE. However, if h = t/(1 +  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ t), then the square has vertices at B (1,0), (1 - h,    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0), (1 - h, h), (1, h). The vertex (1 - h, h) is on AE, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ and (1, h) is not on AE unless h = t. Therefore,        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ depending on which vertex is on AE, we have two         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ different squares. But we need to determine which one   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ is intended by the problem.                             │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given that the problem states "a square with vertex     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ B... and a vertex on AE", not specifying which vertex,  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ but since (1 - h, h) is strictly inside AE (since h < t │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ in this case), whereas (1, h) is on the boundary BC as  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ well. But since the problem says "a vertex on AE", not  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ necessarily exclusively on AE. So both squares satisfy  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ the condition. However, the problem refers to "the      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ smaller square", implying there is only one such        │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ square. Wait, but perhaps only one of these squares is  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ entirely within the original square ABCD.               │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Wait, if h = t ≈ 0.2679, then the square extends from   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ (1,0) to (1 - h, 0) ≈ 0.732, 0, which is still inside   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ ABCD. Similarly, up to (1 - h, h) ≈ (0.732, 0.2679),    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ which is also inside ABCD. So both squares are entirely │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ within ABCD. But the problem says "the smaller square". │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Since h = t/(1 + t) ≈ 0.211 is smaller than h = t ≈     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.2679, so perhaps the answer is h = t/(1 + t).         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ But how to resolve this ambiguity? Let me check the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ problem statement again:                                │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ "A square with vertex B has sides that are parallel to  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ those of ABCD and a vertex on AE."                      │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ It doesn't specify which vertex, but in the first case, │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ where h = t, the square has a vertex at E, which is on  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ both AE and BC. In the second case, the square has a    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ vertex strictly on AE (not on BC). Since the problem    │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ says "a vertex on AE", not "a vertex only on AE", both  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ are valid. However, since they ask for "the length of a │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ side of this smaller square", implying there's only one │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ such square. Therefore, which one is smaller.           │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Indeed, h = t/(1 + t) is smaller than h = t, so the     │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ answer is h = (3 - sqrt(3))/6, which is approximately   │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ 0.211. Let me verify this.                              │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ Given t = 2 - sqrt(3),                                  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ h = t/(1 + t) = (2 - sqrt(3))/(1 + 2 - sqrt(3)) = (2 -  │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │ sqrt(3))/(3 - sqrt(3)).                                 │                      │                    │ │
│ │                                                         │                                                         │                      │                    │ │
